laws.summary: Michigan enforces reasonable non-compete agreements under common law. The Michigan Antitrust Reform Act (MARA) prohibits certain non-competes for some healthcare professionals. Non-competes must be reasonable in scope, duration (typically 1-2 years), and geography, and protect legitimate business interests.
laws.statute_citation: M.C.L. § 445.774a (MARA - healthcare restrictions); Common law for general non-competes
requirements: Must be ancillary to employment relationship
Must protect legitimate business interest (trade secrets, confidential information, customer relationships)
Must be reasonable in duration (typically 1-2 years)
Must be reasonable in geographic scope
Must be reasonable in scope of prohibited activities
Supported by adequate consideration
HEALTHCARE: Physicians employed by hospitals may not be subject to non-competes under MARA in certain circumstances
HEALTHCARE: Cannot restrict physician from practicing medicine in area where they practiced during employment
Courts will apply 'reasonableness' test
Michigan courts may 'blue pencil' unreasonable provisions
Lower-level employees less likely to have enforceable non-competes
laws.notes: Michigan balances employer interests with worker mobility. MARA provides specific protections for physicians. Federal FTC ban blocked in 2024.

laws.summary: Michigan has NO statewide salary history ban. Employers may ask about and consider applicant salary history. No state-level restrictions on salary history inquiries.
requirements: STATEWIDE: No restriction on asking salary history
Employers may ask applicants about prior compensation
Employers may use salary history in setting compensation
No state penalties for salary history inquiries
Federal equal pay laws still apply
Some employers voluntarily avoid asking for equity reasons
laws.notes: Michigan has not enacted salary history ban. Employers have discretion to ask.

laws.summary: Michigan has NO statewide pay transparency law requiring salary ranges in job postings. No requirement to disclose compensation ranges to applicants or employees.
requirements: STATEWIDE: No requirement to include salary ranges in job postings
STATEWIDE: No requirement to disclose pay ranges to applicants
STATEWIDE: No requirement to disclose pay ranges to current employees
STATEWIDE: No pay data reporting requirements
Federal equal pay laws apply
Employers may voluntarily disclose pay ranges
laws.notes: Michigan has not enacted pay transparency legislation.

laws.summary: Michigan has no statewide ban-the-box law for private employers. Employers may ask about criminal history on applications. Must comply with federal FCRA. Michigan courts have held that considering criminal history must be job-related and consistent with business necessity.
laws.statute_citation: Federal FCRA (15 U.S.C. § 1681); Michigan common law
requirements: PRIVATE EMPLOYERS: Can ask about criminal history on applications
PRIVATE EMPLOYERS: No ban-the-box restrictions
FCRA: Must get written consent before background check
FCRA: Must provide pre-adverse action notice with copy of report
FCRA: Must provide final adverse action notice
FCRA: Seven-year lookback for most non-conviction records
FCRA: Ten-year lookback for bankruptcies
FCRA: No time limit on convictions
FCRA: $75,000+ positions exempt from lookback limits
Criminal history consideration must be job-related
Must consider: nature of crime, time elapsed, job duties, rehabilitation
Cannot discriminate based solely on arrest without conviction
laws.notes: Michigan has no ban-the-box law. Federal FCRA and anti-discrimination laws provide primary protections.

laws.summary: Michigan's Earned Sick Time Act (ESTA) requires employers to provide paid sick leave. Amended in February 2025, ESTA requires employees accrue 1 hour of paid sick time for every 30 hours worked. Employers with 10+ employees provide paid leave; smaller employers may provide unpaid. Maximum 72 hours per year (40 hours for small employers).
laws.statute_citation: Michigan Earned Sick Time Act (ESTA), M.C.L. § 408.961 et seq. (amended 2025)
requirements: Applies to all Michigan employers
LARGE EMPLOYERS (10+ employees): Must provide PAID sick time
SMALL EMPLOYERS (fewer than 10): Must provide UNPAID sick time
Accrual: 1 hour per 30 hours worked
Maximum accrual: 72 hours per year (or 40 hours for small employers)
Can use after first day of employment (amended from 90-day wait)
Employers may cap usage at 72 hours (40 for small employers) per year
Employers may cap carryover at 72 hours (40 for small employers)
Front-loading permitted: Can provide 72 hours upfront instead of accrual
If front-loaded, no carryover required
New hires: Employers can require 120-day wait before using accrued leave
Notice: Employee must give notice 'as soon as practicable' for unforeseeable leave
Notice: Up to 7 days advance notice for foreseeable leave
Sick time does not accrue during employee's time off
Use allowed for: employee illness, family member care, medical appointments, domestic violence situations
NOT required to pay out unused sick time at termination
Records must be maintained for 3 years
Effective February 21, 2025
laws.notes: ESTA was reinstated by Michigan Supreme Court and amended in 2025. Significant compliance requirement for all Michigan employers. Replaced earlier version that would have been more expansive.

laws.summary: Michigan generally enforces arbitration agreements under federal and state law. Follows Federal Arbitration Act. Agreements must be clear, mutual, and not unconscionable.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act (9 U.S.C. §§ 1-16); Michigan common law
requirements: Arbitration agreements generally enforceable under FAA
Must be in writing and signed by both parties
Must have mutual agreement to arbitrate
Must identify claims subject to arbitration
Cannot be unconscionable
Must provide for neutral arbitrator
Adequate consideration required
Michigan courts favor arbitration
Class action waivers generally enforceable
Pre-dispute arbitration agreements enforceable
Can be challenged on contract grounds (fraud, duress, unconscionability)
laws.effective_date: Ongoing under federal and state law
laws.notes: Michigan follows federal policy favoring arbitration.

laws.summary: Michigan follows at-will employment doctrine. Either party can terminate employment at any time for any legal reason or no reason. Exceptions exist for discrimination, retaliation, public policy violations, and breach of contract.
laws.statute_citation: Common law doctrine; M.C.L. § 37.2101 et seq. (Elliott-Larsen Civil Rights Act - anti-discrimination)
requirements: Default: Employment terminable at will by either party
No notice required unless contract/policy requires it
Final wages must be paid promptly
EXCEPTIONS - Cannot terminate for: Race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, disability, height, weight, marital status discrimination (Elliott-Larsen Act)
Cannot terminate for: Retaliation (workers' comp, jury duty, whistleblowing)
Cannot terminate for: Violation of public policy
Cannot terminate for: Breach of employment contract
Employment handbooks may create implied contracts if not properly disclaimed
Written employment contracts override at-will status
Union/collective bargaining agreements override at-will status
Michigan courts recognize implied contract exception
laws.notes: Michigan is at-will state with typical exceptions. Elliott-Larsen Act provides broad anti-discrimination protections.

laws.summary: Michigan has limited drug testing restrictions. Medical marijuana users have some protections under Michigan Medical Marihuana Act (MMMA), but employers can maintain drug-free workplace policies. Public employers may enforce zero-tolerance drug policies even for medical marijuana cardholders.
laws.statute_citation: M.C.L. § 333.26424(e) (Michigan Medical Marihuana Act); No general restriction statute
requirements: STATEWIDE: No general restriction on drug testing
Pre-employment testing: Generally permitted
Random testing: Permitted for safety-sensitive positions
Reasonable suspicion testing: Permitted
Post-accident testing: Permitted
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: MMMA provides limited protections
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: Employers not required to accommodate on-site marijuana use
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: Employers can prohibit use or being under the influence at work
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: Michigan Supreme Court ruled public employers may enforce zero-tolerance policies (Eplee v. City of Lansing, 2019)
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: Private employer cases vary - some protection may exist
RECREATIONAL MARIJUANA: No workplace protections
Employers can maintain drug-free workplace policies
Federal DOT requirements apply to transportation positions
Recommended: Written drug testing policy
laws.notes: Michigan medical marijuana law creates complexity. Public employers have broad latitude for zero-tolerance policies. Private employer obligations less clear.
